[[Lithium nitrite]] }} }} '''Sodium nitrite''' is the [[inorganic compound]] with the [[chemical formula]] [[Sodium|Na]][[Nitrite|NO2]]. It is a white to slightly yellowish crystalline powder that is very soluble in [[water]] and is [[hygroscopic]]. It is a useful precursor to a variety of organic compounds, such as pharmaceuticals, dyes, and pesticides, but it is probably best known as a food additive to prevent [[botulism]]. It is on the [[World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines]], the most important medications needed in a basic [[health system]].{{cite web|title=WHO Model List of EssentialMedicines|url=http://www.who.int/entity/medicines/publications/essentialmedicines/EML_2015_FINAL_amended_NOV2015.pdf?ua=1|work=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 September 2016|date=April 2015}} Nitrate or [[nitrite]] (ingested) under conditions that result in endogenous [[nitrosation]] has been classified as "probably carcinogenic to humans" by [[International Agency for Research on Cancer]] (IARC).{{cite web|title=List of classifications, Volumes 1–116 - IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans|url=http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/latest_classif.php|work=International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) - World Health Organization (WHO)|accessdate=25 September 2016|date=2010}}{{cite web|title=VOLUME 94 - Ingested Nitrate and Nitrite, and Cyanobacterial Peptide Toxins - IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans|url=http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Monographs/vol94/index.php|work=International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) - World Health Organization (WHO)|accessdate=25 September 2016|date=2010}} ==Uses== ===Industrial chemistry=== The main use of sodium nitrite is for the industrial production of organonitrogen compounds. It is a reagent for conversion of [[amine]]s into [[diazo]] compounds, which are key precursors to many dyes, such as [[diazo dye]]s. [[Nitroso compound]]s are produced from nitrites. These are used in the rubber industry. It is used in a variety of metallurgical applications, for phosphatizing and detinning.{{cn|date=October 2018}} Sodium nitrite is an effective [[corrosion inhibitor]] and is used as an additive in industrial greases,{{cite journal |last=Krakhmalev |first=S. I. |first2=V. A. |last2=Vorotnikova |first3=N. V. |last3=Ten |first4=N. V. |last4=Taranova |year=1984 |title=Determination of sodium nitrite in complex sodium grease |journal=Chemistry and Technology of Fuels and Oils |volume=20 |issue=12 |pages=612–613 |doi=10.1007/BF00726438 }} as an aqueous solution in closed loop cooling systems, and in a molten state as a heat transfer medium.{{cite web |url= http://www.generalchemical.com/sodium-nitrite.html |title=Sodium Nitrite |publisher=General Chemical |accessdate=2012-09-28}} ===Drugs=== {{Main|Sodium nitrite (medical use)}} Sodium nitrite is used together with [[sodium thiosulfate]] to treat [[cyanide poisoning]].{{cite book|title=WHO Model Formulary 2008|date=2009|publisher=World Health Organization|isbn=9789241547659|pages=65–66|url=http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/documents/s16879e/s16879e.pdf|accessdate= 8 January 2017}} It is in the section "''antidotes and other substances used in poisonings''" of the [[World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines]], the most important medications needed in a basic [[health system]]. ===Food additive=== In the early 1900s, irregular [[curing (food preservation)|curing]] was commonplace. This led to further research surrounding the use of sodium nitrite as an [[Food additive|additive]] in [[food]], standardizing the amount present in foods to minimize the amount needed while maximizing its [[food additive]] role.{{Cite journal|last=Sindelar|first=Jeffrey|first2=Andrew |last2=Milkowski |title=Human safety controversies surrounding nitrate and nitrite in the diet|journal=Nitric Oxide|date=March 2012|doi=10.1016/j.niox.2012.03.011|pmid=22487433|volume=26|issue=4|pages=259–266}} Through this research, sodium nitrite has been found to inhibit growth of disease-causing [[microorganisms]]; give taste and color to the meat; and inhibit lipid oxidation that leads to rancidity. The ability of sodium nitrite to address the above-mentioned issues has led to production of [[meat]] with improved [[food safety]], extended storage life and improving desirable color/taste. It has the [[E number]] E250. [[Potassium nitrite]] (E249) is used in the same way. It is approved for usage in the [[European Union|EU]],UK Food Standards Agency: {{cite web |url=http://www.food.gov.uk/safereating/chemsafe/additivesbranch/enumberlist |title=Current EU approved additives and their E Numbers |accessdate=27 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/food/fs/sc/scf/reports/scf_reports_38.pdf|title=Health and Food Safety|author=|date=|website=European Commission - European Commission|accessdate=1 April 2018}} USAUS Food and Drug Administration: {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/FoodIngredientsPackaging/FoodAdditives/ucm191033.htm#ftnT |title=Listing of Food Additives Status Part II |accessdate=27 October 2011}} and Australia and New Zealand.Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code{{cite web |url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2011C00827 |title=Standard 1.2.4 – Labelling of ingredients |accessdate=27 October 2011}} ====Inhibition of microbial growth==== Sodium nitrite is well known for its role in inhibiting the growth of ''[[Clostridium botulinum]]'' spores in refrigerated meats.{{Cite journal|last=Milkowski|first=Andrew|first2=Harsha |last2=Garg |first3=James|last3= Couglin |first4=Nathan|last4= Bryan |title=Nutritional epidemiology in the context of nitric oxide biology: Risk-Benefit evaluation for dietary nitrite and nitrate|journal=Nitric Oxide|date=January 2010|volume=22|pages=110–119|doi=10.1016/j.niox.2009.08.004|pmid=19748594 |issue=2}} The mechanism for this activity results from the inhibition of [[iron-sulfur clusters]] essential to energy metabolism of ''Clostridium botulinum''. However, sodium nitrite has had varying degrees of effectiveness for controlling growth of other spoilage or disease causing [[microorganisms]]. Even though the inhibitory mechanisms for sodium nitrite are not well known, its effectiveness depends on several factors including residual nitrite level, [[pH]], salt concentration, reductants present and [[iron]] content.{{Cite journal|last=Sindelar|first=Jeffrey|last2=Milkowski|first2=Andrew|date=November 2011|title=Sodium Nitrite in Processed Meat and Poultry Meats: A Review of Curing and Examining the Risk/Benefit of Its Use|url=http://www.meatscience.org/docs/default-source/publications-resources/white-papers/2011-11-amsa-nitrite-white-paper.pdf?sfvrsn=8|journal=American Meat Science Association|volume=3|pages=1–14|via=}} Furthermore, the type of [[bacteria]] also affects sodium nitrites effectiveness. It is generally agreed upon that sodium nitrite is not considered effective for controlling [[gram-negative]] enteric pathogens such as ''[[Salmonella]]'' and ''[[Escherichia coli]]''. ====Taste and color==== The [[Visual appearance|appearance]] and [[taste]] of meat is an important component of consumer acceptance. Sodium nitrite is responsible for the desirable red color (or shaded pink) of meat. Very little nitrite is needed to induce this change. It has been reported that as little as 2 to 14 parts per million (ppm) is needed to induce this desirable [[color]] change. However, to extend the lifespan of this color change, significantly higher levels are needed. The mechanism responsible for this color change is the formation of nitrosylating agents by [[nitrite]], which has the ability to transfer [[nitric oxide]] that subsequently reacts with [[myoglobin]] to produce the [[curing (food preservation)|cured]] meat color. The unique taste associated with cured meat is also affected by the addition of sodium nitrite. However, the mechanism underlying this change in taste is still not fully understood. ====Inhibition of lipid oxidation==== Sodium nitrite is also able to effectively delay the development of [[oxidative]] [[rancidity]]. [[Lipid oxidation]] is considered to be a major reason for the deterioration of quality of meat products ([[rancidity]] and unappetizing flavors). Sodium nitrite acts as an [[antioxidant]] in a mechanism similar to the one responsible for the coloring affect. Nitrite reacts with [[heme]] proteins and metal ions, neutralizing [[free radicals]] by [[nitric oxide]] (one of its byproducts). Neutralization of these [[free radicals]] terminates the cycle of [[lipid oxidation]] that leads to [[rancidity]]. ==Toxicity== While this chemical will prevent the growth of bacteria, it can be toxic in high amounts for animals and humans. Sodium nitrite's [[median lethal dose|LD50]] in rats is 180 mg/kg and its human [[lowest published lethal dose|LDLo]] is 71 mg/kg, meaning a 65 kg person would likely have to consume at least 4.6 [[gram|g]] to result in death.http://msds.chem.ox.ac.uk/SO/sodium_nitrite.html To prevent toxicity, sodium nitrite (blended with salt) sold as a food additive is dyed bright pink to avoid mistaking it for plain salt or sugar. Nitrites are not naturally occurring in vegetables in significant quantities.{{cite encyclopedia | doi = 10.1016/B0-12-227055-X/00830-0 | title = Encyclopedia of Food Sciences and Nutrition | year = 2003 | last1 = Dennis | first1 = M. J. | last2 = Wilson | first2 = L. A. | page = 4136 | chapter = Nitrates and Nitrites | isbn = 978-0-12-227055-0}} However, nitrates are found in commercially available vegetables and a study in an intensive agricultural area in northern Portugal found residual nitrate levels in 34 vegetable samples, including different varieties of cabbage, lettuce, spinach, parsley and turnips ranged between 54 and 2440 mg/kg, e.g. curly kale (302.0 mg/kg) and green cauliflower (64 mg/kg).{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.jfca.2008.10.025 | title = Effects of some processing methods on nitrate and nitrite changes in cruciferous vegetables | year = 2009 | last1 = Leszczyńska | first1 = Teresa | last2 = Filipiak-Florkiewicz | first2 = Agnieszka | last3 = Cieślik | first3 = Ewa | last4 = Sikora | first4 = ElżBieta | last5 = Pisulewski | first5 = Paweł M. | journal = Journal of Food Composition and Analysis | volume = 22 | pages = 315–321 | issue = 4}}{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.foodchem.2009.11.030 | title = Contribution of different vegetable types to exogenous nitrate and nitrite exposure | year = 2010 | last1 = Correia | first1 = Manuela | last2 = Barroso | first2 = Ângela | last3 = Barroso | first3 = M. Fátima | last4 = Soares | first4 = Débora | last5 = Oliveira | first5 = M. B. P. P. | last6 = Delerue-Matos | first6 = Cristina | journal = Food Chemistry | volume = 120 | pages = 960–966 | issue = 4| hdl = 10400.22/3054 }} Boiling vegetables lowers nitrate but not nitrite. Fresh meat contains 0.4–0.5 mg/kg nitrite and 4–7 mg/kg of nitrate (10–30 mg/kg nitrate in cured meats). The presence of nitrite in animal tissue is a consequence of metabolism of [[nitric oxide]], an important neurotransmitter.{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0378-4347(94)00310-6 | title = Measurement of nitrite and nitrate levels in biological samples by capillary electrophoresis | year = 1994 | last1 = Meulemans | first1 = A. | last2 = Delsenne | first2 = F. | journal = Journal of Chromatography B | volume = 660 | pages = 401–404 | issue = 2}} Nitric oxide can be created ''[[wiktionary:de novo|de novo]]'' from [[nitric oxide synthase]] utilizing [[arginine]] or from ingested [[nitrate]] or [[nitrite]].{{cite journal | doi = 10.1006/niox.1998.0187 | pmid = 9851368 | title = Nitrogen Oxides and Hydroxyguanidines: Formation of Donors of Nitric and Nitrous Oxides and Possible Relevance to Nitrous Oxide Formation by Nitric Oxide Synthase | first2 = A | year = 1998 | last2 = Srinivasan | last1 = Southan | first1 = G | journal = Nitric Oxide | volume = 2 | issue = 4 | pages = 270–86}} ===Humane toxin for feral hog/wild boar control=== Because of sodium nitrite's high level of toxicity to swine (''Sus scrofa'') it is now being developed in Australia to control feral pigs and [[wild boar]].{{Cite journal|last=Lapidge|first=Steven|first2=J. |last2=Wishart |first3=M. |last3=Smith |first4=L. |last4=Staples |title=Is America Ready for a Humane Feral Pig Toxicant?|journal=Proceedings of the 13th Wildlife Damage Management Conference|year=2009|pages=49–59}}{{Cite journal|last=Cowled|first=B. D.|first2=S. J. |last2=Lapidge |first3=S. |last3=Humphrys |first4=L. |last4=Staples |title=Nitrite Salts as Poisons in Baits for Omnivores|journal=International Patent WO/2008/104028|year=2008|url=http://www.wipo.int/patentscope/search/en/WO2008104028}} The sodium nitrite induces [[methemoglobinemia]] in swine, i.e. it reduces the amount of oxygen that is released from hemoglobin, so the animal will feel faint and pass out, and then die in a humane manner after first being rendered unconscious.{{Cite book|first1=S. |last1=Porter |first2=T. |last2=Kuchel|title=Assessing the humaness and efficacy of a new feral pig bait in domestic pigs. Study PC0409|year=2010|publisher=Veterinary Services Division, Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science|location=Canberra, South Australia|page=11|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/pubs/pigs-imvs-report.pdf}} The [[Texas Parks and Wildlife Department]] operates a research facility at [[Kerr Wildlife Management Area]], where they examine feral pig feeding preferences and bait tactics to administer sodium nitrite.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GigpxLNbgeg&spfreload=1|title=Hogs Wild - Fighting the Feral Pig Problem - Texas Parks and Wildlife [Official]|last=Texas Parks and Wildlife|date=21 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=1 April 2018|via=YouTube}} ===Nitrosamine=== A principal concern about sodium nitrite is the formation of [[carcinogen]]ic [[nitrosamine]]s in meats containing sodium nitrite when meat is charred or overcooked. Such carcinogenic nitrosamines can also be formed from the reaction of nitrite with secondary amines under acidic conditions (such as occurs in the human stomach) as well as during the [[Curing (food preservation)|curing process]] used to preserve meats. Dietary sources of nitrosamines include US cured meats preserved with sodium nitrite as well as the dried salted fish eaten in Japan. In the 1920s, a significant change in US meat curing practices resulted in a 69% decrease in average nitrite content. This event preceded the beginning of a dramatic decline in gastric cancer mortality.{{cite journal|url=http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/30/1/181.full |title=The epidemiological enigma of gastric cancer rates in the US: was grandmother's sausage the cause?|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology |volume=30|issue=1|pages=181–182|date=2000|doi=10.1093/ije/30.1.181|last1=Freeman|first1=Harold P.|last2=Oropeza|first2=Ruben|last3=Saborio|first3=David V.|last4=Paik|first4=David C.}} Around 1970, it was found that [[ascorbic acid]] (vitamin C), an [[antioxidant]], inhibits nitrosamine formation.{{cite journal | url = http://carcin.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/10/2/397 | title = The inhibition of bacterially mediated ''N''-nitrosation by vitamin C: relevance to the inhibition of endogenous ''N''-nitrosation in the achlorhydric stomach | journal = Carcinogenesis | year = 1989 | volume = 10 | issue = 2 | pages = 397–9 | first1= C. W. |last1=Mackerness |first2=S. A. |last2=Leach |first3=M. H. |last3=Thompson |first4=M. J. |last4= Hill | doi = 10.1093/carcin/10.2.397 | pmid = 2492212}} Consequently, the addition of at least 550 ppm of ascorbic acid is required in meats manufactured in the United States. Manufacturers sometimes instead use [[erythorbic acid]], a cheaper but equally effective [[isomer]] of ascorbic acid. Additionally, manufacturers may include [[Alpha-Tocopherol|α-tocopherol (vitamin E)]] to further inhibit nitrosamine production. α-Tocopherol, ascorbic acid, and erythorbic acid all inhibit nitrosamine production by their oxidation-reduction properties. Ascorbic acid, for example, forms [[dehydroascorbic acid]] when [[redox|oxidized]], which when in the presence of [[nitrosonium]], a potent nitrosating agent formed from sodium nitrite, reduces the nitrosonium into [[nitric oxide]].{{cite web|url=http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/publications/research-newsletter|title=Research Newsletter|author=|date=1 July 2014|website=Linus Pauling Institute|accessdate=1 April 2018}} The nitrosonium ion formed in acidic nitrite solutions is commonly{{cite journal |first1=R. A. |last1=Scanlan |title= Formation and occurrence of nitrosamines in food |journal=[[Cancer Res.]] |date=May 1983 |volume=43 |issue=5 Suppl |pages=2435s–2440s |pmid=6831466}}{{cite book | title = Handbook of Food Analysis |edition=Third| year = 2015 | last1 = Nollet, Toldra| first1 = D | page = 290 | isbn = 9781482297843 }} mislabeled nitrous anhydride, an unstable nitrogen oxide that cannot exist in vitro.{{cite book | doi = 10.1016/B978-044451721-0/50002-5 | title = Nitrosation Reactions and the Chemistry of Nitric Oxide | year = 2004 | last1 = Williams | first1 = D | page = 1 | chapter = Reagents effecting nitrosation | isbn = 978-0-444-51721-0 }} Nitrate or [[nitrite]] (ingested) under conditions that result in endogenous [[nitrosation]] has been classified as "probably carcinogenic to humans" by [[International Agency for Research on Cancer]] (IARC).{{cite web|title=List of classifications, Volumes 1–116 - IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans|url=http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/latest_classif.php|work=International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) - World Health Organization (WHO)|accessdate=25 September 2016|date=2010}}{{cite web|title=VOLUME 94 - Ingested Nitrate and Nitrite, and Cyanobacterial Peptide Toxins - IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans|url=http://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Monographs/vol94/index.php|work=International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) - World Health Organization (WHO)|accessdate=25 September 2016|date=2010}} Sodium nitrite consumption has also been linked to the triggering of migraines in individuals who already suffer from them.{{cite web | url = http://permanent.access.gpo.gov/lps1609/www.fda.gov/fdac/features/1998/398_pain.html | title = Heading Off Migraine Pain | publisher = [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] | work = FDA Consumer magazine | year = 1998}} One study has found a correlation between highly frequent ingestion of meats cured with [[Prague Powder#1|pink salt]] and the [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease|COPD]] form of [[lung disease]]. The study's researchers suggest that the high amount of nitrites in the meats was responsible; however, the team did not prove the nitrite theory. Additionally, the study does not prove that nitrites or cured meat caused higher rates of COPD, merely a link. The researchers did adjust for many of COPD's risk factors, but they commented they cannot rule out all possible unmeasurable causes or risks for COPD.{{cite news | url = http://www.webmd.com/news/20070417/study-copd-cured-meats-may-be-linked | title = Study: Cured Meats, COPD May Be Linked | first= Miranda |last=Hitti | publisher = WebMD Medical News | date = 17 April 2007}}{{cite journal | doi = 10.1164/rccm.200607-969OC | pmc = 1899290 | title = Cured Meat Consumption, Lung Function, and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease among United States Adults | pmid = 17255565 | year = 2007 | last1 = Jiang | first1 = R. | last2 = Paik | first2 = D. C. | last3 = Hankinson | first3 = J. L. | last4 = Barr | first4 = R. G. | journal = American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine | volume = 175 | issue = 8 | pages = 798–804}} ==Mechanism of action== Carcinogenic nitrosamines are formed when [[amine]]s that occur naturally in food react with sodium nitrite found in cured meat products. {{block indent|1=R2NH (amines) + NaNO2 (sodium nitrite) → R2N–N=O (nitrosamine)}} In the presence of acid (such as in the stomach) or heat (such as via cooking), nitrosamines are converted to [[diazonium compound|diazonium ions]]. {{block indent|1=R2N–N=O (nitrosamine) + (acid or heat) → {{chem|R–N|2|+}} (diazonium ion)}} Certain nitrosamines such as [[N-nitrosodimethylamine|''N''-nitrosodimethylamine]]{{Cite journal|title=NDMA Formation in Water and Wastewater|last1= Najm|first1= Issam|last2= Trussell|first2= R. Rhodes|journal=Journal AWWA|volume=93|issue=2|date=February 2001|pages=92–99}} and [[N-nitrosopyrrolidine|''N''-nitrosopyrrolidine]]{{Cite journal|title=Potential precursors of ''N''-nitrosopyrrolidine in bacon and other fried foods|first1=Donald D. |last1=Bills |first2=Kjell I. |last2=Hildrum |first3=Richard A. |last3=Scanlan |first4=Leonard M. |last4=Libbey|journal=J. Agric. Food Chem.|volume=21|issue=5|date=May 1973|pages=876–7|doi=10.1021/jf60189a029|pmid=4739004}} form carbocations that react with biological [[nucleophile]]s (such as DNA or an enzyme) in the cell. {{block indent|{{chem|R–N|2|+}} (diazonium ion) → R+ (carbocation) + N2 (leaving group) + Nu (biological nucleophiles) → R–Nu}} If this [[SN1 reaction|nucleophilic substitution]] reaction occurs at a crucial site in a biomolecule, it can disrupt normal cell functions, leading to cancer or [[apoptosis|cell death]]. ==Production== Industrial production of sodium nitrite follows one of two processes, the reduction of nitrate salts, or the oxidation of lower nitrogen oxides. One method uses molten sodium nitrate as the salt, and lead which is oxidized, while a more modern method uses scrap iron filings to reduce the nitrate.Wolfgang Laue, Michael Thiemann, Erich Scheibler, Karl Wilhelm Wiegand "Nitrates and Nitrites" in ''Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry'', 2002, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.{{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a17_265}}. Article Online Posting Date: 15 June 2000{{cite journal|last1=Hao|first1=Zhi-wei|last2=Xu|first2=Xin-hua|last3=Wang|first3=Da-hui|title=Reductive denitrification of nitrate by scrap iron filings|journal=Journal of Zhejiang University SCIENCE|date=March 2005|volume=6B|issue=3|pages=182–186|doi=10.1631/jzus.2005.B0182|pmid=15682502|pmc=1389719}} A more commonly used method involves the general reaction of nitrogen oxides in alkaline aqueous solution, with the addition of a catalyst. The exact conditions depend on which nitrogen oxides are used, and what the oxidant is, as the conditions need to be carefully controlled to avoid over oxidation of the nitrogen atom. Sodium nitrite has also been produced by reduction of nitrate salts by exposure to heat, light, ionizing radiation, metals, hydrogen, and electrolytic reduction.Pokorny L et al; "Sodium Nitrate and Nitrite" in "Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology", 2005, NY, NY: John Wiley & Sons. ==Chemical reactions== In the laboratory, sodium nitrite can be used to destroy excess [[sodium azide]].{{cite web | url = http://www.ehs.neu.edu/hazardous_waste/fact_sheets/sodium_azide/ | work = Hazardous Waste Management | title = Sodium Azide | date = March 2003 | publisher = [[Northeastern University]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071104105622/http://www.ehs.neu.edu/hazardous_waste/fact_sheets/sodium_azide/ | archivedate = 4 November 2007 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite book | title = Prudent practices in the laboratory: handling and disposal of chemicals | year = 1995 | publisher = [[National Academy Press]] | location = Washington, D.C. | isbn = 978-0-309-05229-0 | url = http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=4911&page=165 | author = Committee on Prudent Practices for Handling, Storage, and Disposal of Chemicals in Laboratories, Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology, Commission on Physical Sciences, Mathematics, and Applications, National Research Council}} {{block indent|2 NaN3 + 2 NaNO2 + 4 H+ → 3 N2 + 2 NO + 4 Na+ + 2 H2O}} Above 330 °C sodium nitrite decomposes (in air) to [[sodium oxide]], [[nitric oxide]] and [[nitrogen dioxide]].{{cite journal |last=Stern |first=Kurt H. |date=1972 |title=High Temperature Properties and Decomposition of Inorganic Salts; Part 3. Nitrates and Nitrites |url=https://www.nist.gov/data/PDFfiles/jpcrd11.pdf |journal= J. Phys. Chem.|volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=750–751 |accessdate=15 March 2014 | doi = 10.1063/1.3253104 }} {{block indent|2 NaNO2 → Na2O + NO + NO2}} Sodium nitrite can also be used in the production of [[nitrous acid]] via [[sulfuric acid]]. This reaction first yields [[nitrous acid]] and [[sodium sulfate]]: {{block indent|2 {{chem|NaNO|2}} + {{chem|H|2|SO|4}} → 2 {{chem|HNO|2}} + {{chem|Na|2|SO|4}}}} The nitrous acid then, under normal conditions, decomposes: {{block indent|2 {{chem|HNO|2}} → {{chem|NO|2}} + NO + {{chem|H|2|O}}}} The nitrogen dioxide of the prior decomposition is then routed through a [[condenser (laboratory)|condensor]] or [[fractional distillation|fractional distillation apparatus]] to react with water and yield both nitric and nitrous acids: {{block indent|2 {{chem|NO|2}} + {{chem|H|2|O}} → {{chem|HNO|3}} + {{chem|HNO|2}}}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/csem/nitrate/ ATSDR – Case Studies in Environmental Medicine – Nitrate/Nitrite Toxicity] U.S. [[Department of Health and Human Services]] (public domain) * [http://www.inchem.org/documents/icsc/icsc/eics1120.htm International Chemical Safety Card 1120]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050402124230/http://www.uga.edu/nchfp/how/cure_smoke/nitrates_nitrites.html National Center for Home Food Preservation Nitrates and Nitrites]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051122171331/http://ntp-server.niehs.nih.gov/index.cfm?objectid=070B04E4-0E6C-7453-7747FB268B93D146 TR-495: Toxicology and Carcinogenesis Studies of Sodium Nitrite (CAS NO. 7632-00-0) Drinking Water Studies in F344/N Rats and B6C3F1 Mice]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110101140455/http://www.extension.umn.edu/distribution/nutrition/DJ0974.html Nitrite in Meat] page.title: South Korea Ballistic Missile Range Guidelines

revision.text:
[[File:Card Stunt for Park Chung-hee.jpg|thumb|South Korean [[Hyunmoo]]-1 (NHK, [[Nike Hercules]] Korea) missiles, with a range of about 140 km, on display in 1973]] In 1979, '''[[South Korea]]''' agreed to '''ballistic missile guidelines''', limiting the country’s ballistic missile development and possession to 180 [[Kilometre|km]] in range.<ref>{{cite news|last=김|first=광수|title=한국 미사일 사거리 800km로 늘린다|url=http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/politics/201209/h2012092402340721000.htm|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=한국일보}}</ref>
In 2001, United States officials agreed to extend the range limit to 300 km, which only applied to high-velocity, free flight ballistic missiles, excluding slower, surface-skimming cruise weapons. South Korea developed an [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] (UAV) and [[cruise missile]] called [[Hyunmoo-3]]. The UAV would not have any limitation in range while the cruise missile’s range was 1500 kilometers (930 miles).<ref name=nyt-20121007>{{cite news|last=Choe|first=Sang-Hun|title=U.S. Agrees to Let South Korea Extend Range of Ballistic Missiles|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/08/world/asia/us-agrees-to-let-south-korea-extend-missile-range.html?_r=3&|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=7 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Eshel|first=Tamir|title=Hyunmoo Missiles – Seoul Going Ballistic|url=http://defense-update.com/20120422_new_hyunmoo_korean_missiles.html|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=Defense Update}}</ref> South Korea's missile ranges were less than North Korea’s missiles such as Rodong (1300 kilometer-ranged ballistic missile) and [[Taepodong-2]] (6000 kilometer-ranged intercontinental ballistic missile).<ref>{{cite news|last=Davenport|first=Kelsey|title=South Korea Extends Missile Range|url=http://www.armscontrol.org/act/2012_11/South-Korea-Extends-Missile-Range|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=Arms Control Association}}</ref>
On October 6, 2012, after numerous caucuses between South Korea and the U.S., both agreed to extend the [[ballistic missile]] range to 800 km.<ref name=nyt-20121007/> This was shorter than the range South Korea suggested (1000 kilometers) but much longer than the existing 300 km limit.<ref>{{cite news|last=윤|first=상호|title=美 국방 "한국 미사일 사거리 연장 상당한 진전"|url=http://news.donga.com/3/all/20120616/47052108/1|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=DongA News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Dudley|first=Richard|title=US and South Korea Agree to Extend Missile Range|url=http://defense-update.com/20121008_us-and-south-korea-agree-to-extend-missile-range.html|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=Defense Update}}</ref>
After the latest missile guideline extension, one particular Chinese media reported that South Korea’s ballistic missiles would gain the capability to reach [[China]], [[Japan]], and [[Russia]] as well as [[North Korea]]. The media showed concerns over the possibility of a South Korean attack on [[Beijing]], should the South’s missile range be extended. Another Chinese media outlet, Shinhwa, evaluated that the extension of the missile range as a violation against the [[Missile Technology Control Regime]] (MTCR).<ref>{{cite news|last=박|first=희준|title=中신화"한국 탄도미사일 사거리 연장은 MTCR위배"|url=http://view.asiae.co.kr/news/view.htm?idxno=2012100715340010694&nvr=Y|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=아시아경제}}</ref> Japan raised concerns of heightened resistance by North Korea.<ref>{{cite news|last=박|first=철원|title=일, 한국 미사일 사거리 연장에 "경계"|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=104&oid=034&aid=0002430342|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=YTN}}</ref> The Russian Department of External Affairs opposed the extension of South Korea’s missile range, through the column of Alexander Lukashcvich, spokesperson of Department of External Affairs.<ref>{{cite news|title=러시아, 한국 미사일 사거리 연장에 우려 표명(종합)|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=001&aid=0005862167|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=연합뉴스}}</ref> [[North Korea]] stated that they would strengthen their military force in response to the extension. North Korea stated that their rockets were capable of reaching South Korea, Japan, Guam, and even the US. North Korea also said they would ‘respond to nuclear weapons with nuclear weapons, and respond to missiles with missiles’ as stated by the National Defense Committee. The National Defense Committee also stated the only thing left was resolute action and that they would show the world an ‘unimaginable war’.<ref>{{cite news|last=김|first=근삼|title=북한, 한국 미사일 사거리 연장 강력 비난…한국·버마 정상회담, 경제협력 논의|url=http://www.voakorea.com/content/article/1523061.html|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=Voice of America}}</ref> Jay Carney, the spokesperson of the White House, briefed that the agreement for extending the missile range was to improve South Korea’s defense capacity to face the threats of North Korea’s ballistic missiles. He also emphasized that the alliance between the U.S. and South Korea focused on the mission to keep the Korean peninsula, and Southeast Asia safe, and the U.S. would keep to their pledge of defending South Korea steadily.<ref>{{cite news|last=윤|first=국한|title=백악관 "한국 미사일 사거리 연장, 합당한 조치"|url=http://www.voakorea.com/content/article/1522176.html|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=Voice of America}}</ref>
In 2017 South Korea tested an 800 km range [[Hyunmoo|Hyunmoo-2C]] missile.<ref name=diplomat-20170407>{{cite news |url=http://thediplomat.com/2017/04/south-korea-test-fires-new-ballistic-missile/ |title=South Korea Test Fires New Ballistic Missile |last=Gady |first=Franz-Stefan |publisher=The Diplomat |date=7 April 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>
On 4 September 2017, U.S. President Donald Trump agreed “in principle” to scrap a warhead weight limit on South Korea’s missiles in the wake of North Korea’s sixth nuclear test.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-missiles-southkorea-usa/trump-agrees-in-principle-to-scrap-south-korean-warhead-weight-limit-white-house-idUKKCN1BF1XM |title=Trump agrees 'in principle' to scrap South Korean warhead weight limit - White House |last=|first= |publisher=Reuters News |date=4 September 2017 |accessdate=5 September 2017}}</ref>

population.{{cite book|author=Andrea Carla|chapter=Tensions and Challenges between New and Old minorities: Political Party Discourses on Migration in South Tyrol|editor1=Roberta Medda-Windischer|editor2=Patricia Popelier|title=Pro-independence Movements and Immigration: Discourse, Policy and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=szHFDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA70|year=2016|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-29439-4|page=70}} The party is committed to the [[South Tyrolean secessionist movement]], which entails secession of the Province from [[Italy]] and its reunification with the State of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]] within [[Austria]]. ==History== [[File:Freedompartybanner.jpg|thumb|Banner used in protests helmed by South Tyrolean Freedom.]] The South Tyrolean Freedom emerged as a split from the [[Citizens' Union for South Tyrol|Union for South Tyrol]] (UfS) in May 2007.http://www.stol.it/nachrichten/artikel.asp?KatID=fa&ArtID=93075 On 8 June 2007 it was notarially founded in [[Brixen]]. The founding members were Herbert Campidell, Eva Klotz, Sven Knoll, Reinhold Ladurner, Roland Lang, Sepp Mitterhofer, Werner Thaler and Dietmar Zwerger. In the summer of 2007, the party presented a provocative poster campaign with the slogan "South Tyrol is not Italy" and the [[Flag of Austria|Austrian flag]] as background.http://www.suedstern.org/data/press/Dolomiten_140707.pdf A sign with the same content was set up at the [[Brenner Pass]] border, at last in June 2008.[http://www.vienna.at/news/chronik/artikel/umstrittene-sued-tirol-tafel-wieder-am-brenner-aufgestellt/cn/news-20080615-03201758 Umstrittene "Süd-Tirol-Tafel" wieder am Brenner aufgestellt - Welt Vorarlberg - Vienna Online] In April 2009 the STF became a full member of the [[European Free Alliance]], a pan-European organization of [[Regionalism (politics)|regionalist]] parties.[http://www.e-f-a.org/whos-who/member-parties/ Member Parties] Gudrun Kofler from the STF Youth (''Junge Süd-Tiroler Freiheit'') was elected as Vice President of the EFA Youth. In January 2012 it was reported that the party had reached 2,800 members, a lot more than UfS in its best days. In the [[Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol provincial elections, 2013|2013 provincial election]] the STF won 7.2%, its record high so far, resulting in three provincial councillors.[http://elezioni.provincia.bz.it/ Referendum provinciale confermativo 2014 | Provincia autonoma di Bolzano – Alto Adige] In November 2014 Klotz, who had served in the Provincial Council for 31 consecutive years, announced her resignation from the assembly in order to take care of her husband, who was severely ill.{{cite web |url=http://altoadige.gelocal.it/bolzano/cronaca/2014/11/17/news/clamoroso-eva-klotz-si-dimette-dal-consiglio-provinciale-1.10327041 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141120125051/http://altoadige.gelocal.it/bolzano/cronaca/2014/11/17/news/clamoroso-eva-klotz-si-dimette-dal-consiglio-provinciale-1.10327041 |archivedate=2014-11-20 |df= }}http://derstandard.at/2000008261930/Suedtirol-Eva-Klotz-steigt-aus-Landtag-aushttp://www.tt.com/politik/landespolitik/9274319-91/verfechterin-der-selbstbestimmung-in-s%C3%BCdtirol-eva-klotz-tritt-zur%C3%BCck.csp ==Ideology== The STF sees itself as a "[[liberalism|liberal]]-[[patriotism|patriotic]]" party aimed at protecting the [[German language|German-speaking]] population of South Tyrol. The party claims South Tyroleans' right to self-determination and to conduct a referendum in order to decide whether they want to be part of Italy or the Austrian state of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]]. The party programme also emphasizes the protection of the environment, the defense of family values, a moderately liberal economic policy and the concept of Europe of the regions.http://www.suedtiroler-freiheit.com/content/view/15/28/ ==Election results== ===Provincial Council=== {| class=wikitable |- | colspan=7|[[Landtag of South Tyrol]] |- ! [[File:Hrr.jpg|right|300px]] '''Supreme Ruthenian Council''' ({{lang-uk|Головна Руска Рада}}, Holovna ruska rada, or HRR) was first legal Ruthenian political organization that existed in 1848-1851.
It was founded on 2 May 1848 in Lemberg (today [[Lviv]]), [[Austrian Empire]] as the result of the 1848 [[Spring of Nations]] and in response to the earlier created by the local Polish community Central National Council which claim itself as the representative body of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]]. In its manifest of 10 May 1848 the council declared about the unity of all 15 million [[Ukrainian people]] and expressed its support for all people of the [[Austrian Empire]].
The organization had three main political requests. * divide Galicia into two separate administrative units western for Poles and eastern for Ukrainians * unite into one province all Ukrainian lands of Galicia, Subcarpathia, and Bucovina * lectures in schools and publishing of government statements need to be conducted in [[Ukrainian language]]
Supreme Ruthenian Council consisted of 30 members who were representatives of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] and [[intelligentsia]]. Head of the council was elected bishop of Premissel [[Hryhoriy Yakhymovych]], later canon [[Mykhailo Kuzemsky]]. Yakhymovych's assistants were Mykhailo Kuzemsky and [[Ivan Borysykevych]]. The council contained several departments.
Three members of the organization attended the [[Prague Slavic Congress, 1848|Prague Slavic Congree]] in June 1848.
==See also== * [[Prague Slavic Congress, 1848]] * [[Ruthenian sobor]]
== External links == * [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CR%5CU%5CRuthenianCongress.htm Ruthenian Congress in the Encyclopedia of Ukraine, vol. 3 (1993)] * [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CU%5CSupremeRuthenianCouncil.htm Supreme Ruthenian Council in the Encyclopedia of Ukraine, vol. 3 (1993)]

England & Wales | founder = Charles Delingpole | dissolved = | location_city = Brighton | location_country = England, U.K. | locations = | area_served = Global | key_people = {{unbulleted list|Chris Newson (Chairman & CEO)|Pete Barnes (COO)|Marcus Palmer (CFO)|Dave Ray (CMO)|Rob Hardy (Sales Director)||}} | products = | brands = Get Revising, Marked by Teachers | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = Chris Newson, Charles Delingpole + others | num_employees = 55 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|TSRMatters.com}} | footnotes = | bodystyle = }} '''The Student Room Group''' (often referred to as TSR) is a UK based privately held student community company. It owns three major student facing websites: As well as TheStudentRoom.co.uk, the company also owns MarkedByTeachers.com and GetRevising.co.uk. Its corporate website is TSRMatters.com. This article is about the company as a whole, which refers to itself as The Student Room.{{cite web|title=TSR Group website|url=http://tsrmatters.com/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=15 May 2014}} ==TheStudentRoom.co.uk== {{Infobox website | url = [http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk thestudentroom.co.uk] | alexa = {{Increase}} 6,282 ({{as of|2016|07|08|alt=July 2016}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/thestudentroom.co.uk |title= Thestudentroom.co.uk Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] | accessdate= 2016-07-08 }} |name = The Student Room |area_served = Worldwide with UK bias |key_people = Chris Newson, Chief Executive Officer |num_employees =60 |location = [[United Kingdom]] |type = Student Community and Social Learning Site |language = English; also features a dedicated multilingual sub-forum |registration = Required to post. Viewable as a guest. |owner = [http://tsrmatters.com The Student Room Group Ltd.] |founder= Charles Delingpole |author = }} The Student Room (often abbreviated to TSR), established in 1999, is a large [[United Kingdom]] based community and social learning website for school and university students. It claims to be the no.1 UK education site according to Comscore{{cite web|title=Virtual Community Summit Speakers|url=http://www.virtualcommunitysummit.com/speakers/#.U2DnAPldWQk|publisher=Virtual Community Summit|accessdate=30 April 2014}} media metrix web statistics.{{cite web|title=World’s largest online student community launches a revolution in social learning to millions of UK students|url=http://tsrmatters.com/worlds-largest-online-student-community-launches-a-revolution-in-social-learning-to-millions-of-uk-students/|publisher=The Student Room Group}} It connects students with other students so that they can make more informed education choices, get help with their studies, and get support with student life. As of January 2014, the site has over 1.35 million members and 45 million posts, and gets over 6.5 Million visitors per month.[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/forums Forum Homepage] 16-09-2013 In May 2013 the site incorporated versions of sites MarkedbyTeachers.com and GetRevising.co.uk to form a new social learning section called Learn Together.[http://insight.thestudentroom.co.uk/1n51ght/world%E2%80%99s-largest-online-student-community-launches-a-revolution-in-social-learning-to-millions-of-uk-students/ Press Release] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130610182036/http://insight.thestudentroom.co.uk/1n51ght/world%E2%80%99s-largest-online-student-community-launches-a-revolution-in-social-learning-to-millions-of-uk-students/ |date=2013-06-10 }} 16-05-2013 ==MarkedbyTeachers.com== www.markedbyteachers.com uses selected examples of real student work to help students learn. It has 150,000+ pieces of work written by UK students,{{cite web|title=Marked by Teachers Home Page|url=http://www.markedbyteachers.com/|website=Marked by Teachers|accessdate=16 June 2014}} of which many are also critiqued by UK teachers or peer reviewed by students.{{cite web|title=Marked by Teachers Why Sign Up|url=http://www.markedbyteachers.com/why-sign-up/|website=Marked by Teachers|accessdate=16 June 2014}} ==GetRevising.co.uk== www.getrevising.co.uk contains a broad range of supplementary social learning tools including flashcards, quizzes, word searches, mindmaps, crosswords, revision notes, quiz searches and revision cards. Students create their own resources which they can then share with peers.{{cite web|title=Get Revising - create a resource|url=http://getrevising.co.uk/make|website=Get Revising|accessdate=16 June 2014}} Get Revising is also home to a study planner & revision timetable creator. ==Awards== *The Student Room was announced as one of 3 winners in the Edtech20 Awards announced at the 2014 Edtech Europe conference. This recognises the company as being in the top 3 most innovative and fastest growing Edtech companies in Europe.{{cite web|title=EDTECH 20 2014 – The Winners: Bettermarks, BUSUU, The Student Room Group|url=http://www.edukwest.com/edtech-20-2014-winners-bettermarks-busuu-student-room-group/|website=edukwest.com|publisher=Edukwest|accessdate=16 June 2014}} *The Student Room was the winner of the Fastest Growing Business Award at the Brighton & Hove Business Awards in 2013.{{cite web|title=Brighton & Hove Business Awards 2013 Winners|url=http://www.bahba.co.uk/winners/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=14 May 2014}} *The Student Room wins 4 prestigious Lovies Awards in 2013 for Best Community Site & Best Youth Site awarded by the judges, and the same 2 categories as voted by web users across Europe.{{cite web|title=Lovie Awards Winners 2013|url=http://winners.lovieawards.eu/|website=Lovie Awards|publisher=Lovie Awards|accessdate=19 June 2014}} *The Student Room recognised as an Official Honoree for Social Media Websites at the Webbys{{cite web|title=The Student Room recognised as an Official Honoree for Social Media Websites at the Webbys|url=http://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2014/web/general-website/social-media/honorees|publisher=The Webby Awards|accessdate=14 Nov 2014}} *GetRevising.co.uk wins Hi5 eLearning award from UK government funded Joint Information Systems Committee, the UK body concerned with information and communications technology in education.{{cite web|title=Hi5 Newsletter - Summer 2010|agency=Joint Information Systems Committee, the UK body concerned with information and communications technology in education|url=http://www.jiscrsc.ac.uk/media/49884/newsletter_hi5_2010_final_page_proof.pdf|website=www.jiscrs.ac.uk|publisher=JISC|accessdate=19 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104010057/http://www.jiscrsc.ac.uk/media/49884/newsletter_hi5_2010_final_page_proof.pdf|archivedate=4 November 2014|df=}} *GetRevising.co.uk selected as finalist in the 2010 BETT Awards in the category for Best Tools for Learning and Teaching{{cite web|title=National Web Archive|url=https://www.theguardian.com/resource/winners-and-finalists/|website=theguardian.com|accessdate=14 Nov 2014}} *GetRevising.co.uk has claimed a Silver Award for Most Dramatic Business Impact at the Which Test Won 2014 Online Testing Awards.{{cite web|title=Get Revising Wins Testing Award|url=http://tsrmatters.com/get-revising-wins-testing-award/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=14 May 2014}} *The Student Room medical forums voted Best on the Web by medicalnoises.com {{cite web|title=The Student Room's medical forums voted best on the web|url=http://tsrmatters.com/the-student-rooms-medical-forums-voted-best-on-the-web/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=14 May 2014}} *The Student Room wins INTO's Most Innovative and Useful Site for Students in 2013{{cite web|title=The Student Room wins award for most original, innovative and useful site for students|url=http://blog.intohigher.com/studying-abroad/into-web-awards-march-winner-announced/|publisher=INTO|accessdate=14 Nov 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141114111714/http://blog.intohigher.com/studying-abroad/into-web-awards-march-winner-announced/|archivedate=14 November 2014|df=}} *Ernst & Young short-listed for ‘Best use of Social Media Platform’ for graduate recruitment campaign on The Student Room{{cite web|title=Ernst & Young shortlised for best use of social media platform|url=http://tsrmatters.com/ernst-young-short-listed-for-best-use-of-social-media-platform-for-graduate-recruitment-campaign-on-the-student-room/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=14 May 2014}} The Student Room also runs its own annual "Student in a Million" awards, to identify inspirational UK students.{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Nik|title=Student in a Million Awards 2013|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/content.php?r=335-Student-in-a-Million-the-winners|publisher=The Student Room Group}} In 2013 David Willetts MP, Minister for Universities and Science, presented the awards whilst also opening The Student Room's new Brighton office.{{cite web|last=Shooks|title=Student in a Million awards: celebrating success, remembering Lana Jennifer Maartens|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/showthread.php?t=2358377|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=30 April 2014}} ==Partnerships== The Student Room Group has a range of high-profile partnerships in the student information space. *In 2009 they partnered with the UK Government Department for Innovation Universities and Skills{{cite web|last=Gray|first=Steph|title=Going where the people are|url=http://postbureaucrat.com/2009/02/05/going-where-the-people-are/|publisher=Post Bureaucrat|accessdate=30 April 2014}} (now DBIS - the Department of Business Innovation & Skills)to provide university information for Mature Students. *For several years The Student Room have partnered with UCAS{{cite web|last=Cunningham|first=Matthew|title=UCAS and The Student Room will work together to help students during results and clearing|url=http://tsrmatters.com/ucas-and-the-student-room-will-work-together-to-help-students-during-results-and-clearing/|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=30 April 2014}} to ensure that the moderators on The Student Room are formally trained up as UCAS Advisers, and duly supported by UCAS to ensure they provide high quality advice - particularly during the university Clearing process. *The Student Loans Company (part of Student Finance England) partner with The Student Room{{cite web|title=Student Finance Zone by Student Loans Company|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/content.php?r=399-student-finance|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=30 April 2014}} to ensure that UK students receive the highest quality and most timely advice directly within their own community on The Student Room. ==Ownership, Staff & volunteers== ===Executive Leadership=== The Student Room Group is run by Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Chris Newson, along with his leadership team, Pete Barnes (Chief Operating Officer), Marcus Palmer (Chief Financial Officer), Dave Ray (Chief Marketing Officer), and Rob Hardy (Sales Director).{{cite web|title=TSR Group - Meet the Team|url=http://tsrmatters.com/find-out-about-us/meet-the-team/|website=TSR Matters|publisher=TSR Group|accessdate=27 April 2016}} ===Other Employees=== There are around 70 employees based out of their Brighton office. ===Shareholders=== Chris Newson (username "ChrisN") is the Chairman, CEO and largest shareholder of The Student Room Group.[http://tsrmatters.com/find-out-about-us/meet-the-team/ The Student Room team pages] 27-04-2014 ===Volunteers=== The Student Room sites are run by a team of over 150 volunteer Section Leaders, Support Team Members, Community Assistants, Wiki Support Team Members, Personal Statement Helpers, CV Helpers & Specialist Advisers {{cite web|title=Who runs The Student Room?|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/faq.php?faq=about_tsr#faq_privacy_statement|publisher=The Student Room Group|accessdate=14 May 2014}} ====Section Leader==== Section Leaders are long standing model TSR users handpicked for their understanding of TSR and their leadership skills. They specialise in and oversee a specific section of TSR and work closely with the Support Team in that section. The majority of a Section Leader's time is taken up responding to specific user enquiries and providing support and leadership to the other Support Team members. Section Leaders have the final say on moderation matters. They work closely with the Community Team and the entire user community making sure the Members interests are adequately represented. ====Support Team Members==== Support Team members are active and respected members within a specific forum or group of forums. They are selected for their keen interest and positive contributions within that area of TSR. Support Team members are responsible for the day-to-day organisation, moderation and wellbeing of their site area(s). This encompasses everything from patrolling the forum for inappropriate or incorrectly placed posts and threads, dealing with disputes to answering queries and developing articles on the Wiki. In addition, Support Team members work with users in their site area to make recommendations to the Community Team on improvements that could enhance their sub community on TSR. This could be updates to the forum; but also wider resources such as articles, blogs, photos, partnership suggestions etc. ====Community Assistants==== Community Assistants support the Support Team operating in a particularly 'admin intensive' area of the site. They are responsible for keeping their specific forum area orderly, by moving posts, merging threads and tagging threads appropriately. Community Assistants are chosen either by the members of TSR within a sub-community of the site (in the case of the House of Commons and the Model UN) or by the Support Team (in the case of the Personal Statement forum assistants) to perform an important auxiliary role. ====Wiki Support Team Member==== The Wiki Support Team (WST) are members who have shown an interest in the Articles section of the site. Part of their role means they are responsible for patrolling edits that are made to the articles to ensure there is no vandalism or advertising occurring. They also are active in editing the articles themselves and may try to coordinate efforts within the wider site community to develop certain groups of articles. In addition the WST takes a role in discussing the development and improvements to the articles section in the About Wiki forum. ====Personal Statement Helper==== PS Helpers are university undergrads or graduates who volunteer to help other students who are planning to apply through UCAS with the wording of their Personal Statement. TSR Members can submit a draft of their statement that they would like critiqued into one of the Personal Statement Helper Forums. Only PS Helpers are able to see any of these submissions. Anyone can apply to become a PS Helper, as long as they are at University or have graduated. ====CV Helper==== CV Helpers are usually people have entered full-time work who volunteer to help other Members who are planning to apply for jobs through the wording of their CVs and cover letters. TSR Members can submit a draft of their CV or cover letter that they would like critiqued into the CV Helper Forum. Only CV Helpers are able to see any of these submissions. Though there are currently enough CV Helpers, anyone may become one once you have entered full-time work. ====Specialist Advisers==== Specialist Advisers have a particular specialism or expertise that enables them to impart reputable and credible help to TSR users. They may be people from TSR or from outside of the community who help out by share their knowledge and experience with others. A TSR Member may be approached by Admin to become a Specialist Adviser if they have demonstrated that they have a positive persona on the site and are suitably knowledgeable about a topic covered in one of the TSR forums. Alternatively Admin may approach an external professional partner to provide a Specialist Adviser service into an area that it is felt into which real benefit could be given. ==The websites in detail== ===The Student Room Sections=== The main sections of the site are: * Study Help - where students and teachers help each other out. This section now incorporates a range of social learning tools * University Courses - where students can get advice on any university course they may be wanting to study * Universities - with individual forums for each UK university for prospective students to get advice from existing students, and for existing students to connect with each other. The Student Room also has University Guides for every UK university which combine student & official content * Careers * Life & Style * Entertainment (formerly Hobbies and Interests) * Debate & Current Affairs * Chat (formerly TSR Community) The site is designed as a place for UK students and those looking to study at UK universities to find information about studying, courses and careers. There is however a significant international element (who have their own sub forum).[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/forumdisplay.php?f=117 International Lounge - The Student Room] Another section of the site allows members to use a free [[UCAS#Personal statement|personal statement]] checking service for university admissions.[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/wiki/Personal_Statement_Library PS Help] 16-09-2013 Members may post their personal statement in a forum ready for checking. For privacy, only the poster and members of the checking and administration teams (the former consisting of students already at university) may view the statement. For paying members, when this was such a thing, there was a hidden section consisting of around two hundred arcade games and competition league tables, as well as a secret sub-forum. There are also several other benefits to subscribing to the service, which includes access to Learn Together (see above), custom User Titles and larger avatars.[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/misc.php?do=subscribe-to-tsr Subscription options] 16-09-2013 ===The Student Room Discussion=== A large part of The Student Room is the discussion forum, of which the major sections are: *University Applications *University Courses: most subjects have their own sub forum *Universities: most universities or university towns have their own sub forums *Exams *Academic Help: at any educational level though mostly focused on secondary school and college level; each subject with its own sub forum *[[Gap Year]]s *Debate and Discussion: with politics, society, religion, Model Parliament, Model United Nations and philosophy sub forums *Careers: with teaching, armed forces and finance sub forums *Life and Style: with relationships, health, fashion and beauty sub-forums *Entertainment: with sport, entertainment, technology, gaming and computers, travel and motoring sub-forums. In total the whole site has well over 300 forums and sub forums. ====Model House of Commons==== The "Debate and Discussion" section of the forum also hosts a Model Parliament based on the UK Parliamentary system. The Model House of Commons [MHoC] is run by an elected Speaker and is made up of 50 MPs who create and vote on legislation including bills, motions and petitions. Anyone is free to join the MHoC and they can do so by applying to one of the six parties that operate there: the Labour Party, the Conservative & Unionist Party, the Liberal Party, the Libertarian Party, the Socialist Party and National Conservative Party (formerly UKIP). These parties have no affiliation with any real-life party and can have somewhat different ideological stances to real-life parties of the same name. A governmental term lasts 6 months, and the MHoC is currently in its 26th (XXVI) Parliament. The current government is a Conservative/Liberal/National Conservative minority government with Labour in official opposition. ===The Student Room Articles=== As well as the forum, the site has developed its own [[wiki]]: the TSR Wiki. Written and edited by students on a range of academic, university, careers & life subjects. This provides a reference source for prospective and current UK students on matters of institutions, examinations, courses, applying and going to university, student travel, night life, careers and health, and other general topics of interest to students. Two of the largest sections of the wiki provided a wide range of revision notes, covering many subjects from GCSE level through to University level. It also offers dozens of examples of personal statements used to apply to UK universities and colleges. The most popular part of the wiki at the moment however is the Model House of Commons section which provides details of the MHoC Constitution, Hansard and details of all the parties. ===Social Learning Tools=== ==History== The forum was created in around 2001 under the name "UK Learning" as a site for students at university to talk to each other. Since then the forum has grown in popularity and developed into a forum consisting of dozens of sub-forums and thousands of new posts daily. In late 2004 the forum saw a change to its present name of "The Student Room". UK Learning was originally a portal site, the purpose of which was to push traffic towards profit-oriented sites offering various educational resources such as sample coursework, essays and personal statements. The remainder of the site was a [[vBulletin]]-based discussion forum, most of the content of which was derived from [[usenet]] posts to which users of the forum could respond through the forum rather than via a usenet client, which enabled the site to rapidly build content (and thus [[search engine]] driven traffic) while having only a small user base. Thus, UK Learning/The Student Room has never been a profit-oriented site in itself, though as noted above it does attempt to generate income in the form of optional subscriptions paid by users of the site, advertising banners and voluntary donations from users as a means to offset the large running costs of the site. The connection to the aforementioned profit-oriented sites can still be seen on The Student Room but are no longer the focus of the site. In mid-2002 the portal aspect of the site was dropped in favour of focusing the site around the discussion forum, and the site has remained roughly in this state since. In early 2006 the company which owns TSR was taken over. This new owner, known as CN, set about adding advertisements to the site in order to generate revenue for the running costs. This angered several users as a fundraising drive had recently been held, placement of the advertisements was widely considered intrusive and detrimental, and some of the advertisements were arguably inappropriate. In mid-2006 the owner, CN, detailed ideas for the future of The Student Room; as part of this, CN met a small group of the moderators at a meeting in London. Many ideas were put forward and plans discussed, and over the next few months preparatory work took place for The Student Room to undergo a facelift with the addition of many improvements to attract new members,{{cite web|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/faq.php?faq=tsr_cat#meeting|title='The history of The Student Room|accessdate=2007-02-07 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/showthread.php?t=261954|title='Plans for the future of TSR |accessdate=2007-02-07 }} and on 19 September 2007 the new look website was launched. ==Media coverage== In summer 2004 the forum was also the subject of media coverage after examination questions, from papers yet to be sat, were leaked onto the forum. The user claimed the questions were sample exam questions based on the [[Edexcel]] Mathematics exam he was sitting the next day, and asked for help from other users.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/3834291.stm|title='No re-sits' after exam theft|accessdate=2006-11-11|date=24 June 2004|last=Harrison|first=Angela|publisher=BBC}} In May 2007 the site was heavily quoted by the BBC in an article relating to problems faced in an [[Oxford, Cambridge and RSA Examinations|OCR]] A Level Biology Practical exam after reports to the media from an unnamed member. Some users on the site appeared to have been told far too much about the practical exam by their teachers while others heavily criticised and complained about the difficulty of the exam afterwards.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/6685459.stm|title=Anger over A-level science exam|accessdate=2007-05-26|date=24 May 2007|last=Eason|first=Gary|publisher=BBC}} A similar incident was reported in May 2008,{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/7422381.stm | work=BBC News | title=Students 'had hints' before exam | date=28 May 2008 | accessdate=25 May 2010}} again following discussion on OCR Biology A2 practical exams. Following A Level results day in 2007, the wiki section of the site was mentioned in [https://web.archive.org/web/20070825115016/http://education.independent.co.uk/clearing/article2862207.ece an article in the independent] about preparing for university. It mentioned how TSR has a pretty much exhaustive list of what a student had to take to university with them. The site was also mentioned on 16 August 2007 in 'crucial contacts' list for higher education on [http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/displayNode.jsp?nodeId=134233&command=displayContent&sourceNode=133984&contentPK=18126610&folderPk=78481&pNodeId=133952 Nottingham Evening Post website]. In August 2008, the site was featured in a half page article in [[The Times]] as part of their students supplement produced for the A Level results day. The article looked at the content of the site, picking out key features such as the university discussion forums and the personal statement help section.{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/education/student/article4524070.ece |title=Dispelling university myths in The Student Room|accessdate=2008-08-31|date=13 August 2008|last=Goddard|first=Louis|publisher=The Times | location=London}} In February 2009, The Student Room and [[DIUS]] (Department for Innovation, Universities and Skills) worked together to produce a resource for people over the age of 21 considering going back to education. The minisite features an interactive map of universities across the country, video interviews with mature students and profiles of members who went to university as a mature student. In October 2013, the website decided to turn off a feature known as 'negative reputation' (or neg rep for short) which allowed users to negatively rate other users' posts. It was claimed by the moderators that the feature put people off expressing their opinions.http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/showthread.php?t=2490492 The change was met with much consternation, with many users calling for the drastic move's reversal; a few users supported the move as well. == See also == *[[List of Internet forums]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk The Student Room] *[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/forumdisplay.php?f=102 The Model House of Commons] *[http://www.thestudentroom.co.uk/wiki/TSR_Model_House_of_Commons The Model House of Commons Wiki] {{DEFAULTSORT:Student Room, The}} [[Category:Internet forums]] [[Category:Wiki communities]] [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Youth model government]] [[Category:British websites]]
